text: my name is Chris stoner I work at the
Alaska satellite facility up in
Fairbanks Alaska in 2015
we started to work with the cloud we had
an on-prem web object storage system we
elected to move to the cloud mainly for
you know elasticity the ability to build
stuff out over time as we needed to and
for storage and also for compute we
would get some sort of spikes and
reprocessing campaigns where we could
spin up to accept about 150 gigabits per
second of data incoming rate which is
really really high and we can't do that
on Prem after we built out this this
architecture we were pretty comfortable
with the cloud we started to look again
at that opportunity to allow the
researcher direct access to the archive
and that's a very different thing from
how it would be on Prem the they do not
touch the archive directly on Prem but
in the cloud it's quite an opportunity
to bring your compute next to storage is
a lot faster for our nice our mission
the file sizes are really large so 25
gigabytes a piece for one of these files
it will take forever to download we
don't want them to do that so we built
some tooling to allow the researchers to
spin up a full pipeline in the cloud the
pipeline will spin up it will handle the
amount of workload that's that's given
if you put in 10 products it will output
you know 10 output files and spin down
the pipeline as soon as it's done it
runs on the spot market so it's really
cheap which our researchers really love
and they don't have to be you know cloud
experts in order to use it which was
really attractive for us it was a great
way to get them into the bottle
you
[Music]
